Tel/Fax: +86-512-65885890 Tel/Fax: +86-512-65885890 # Corresponding author Abstract With the merits of high energy density, environmental friendliness, and cost effectiveness, lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered as one of the most promising next-generation electrochemical storage systems. However, the notorious polysulfide shuttle effect, which results in low active material utilization and serious capacity fading, severely impedes the practical application of Li-S batteries. Utilizing various electrocatalysts to improve the polysulfide redox kinetics has recently emerged as a promising strategy to address the shuttle effect. Specially, the electronic structure of the electrocatalysts plays a decisive role in determining the catalytic activity to facilitate the polysulfide conversion. Therefore, reasonably modulating the electronic structure of electrocatalysts is of paramount significance for improving the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Herein, a comprehensive overview of the fascinating strategies to tailor the electronic structure of electrocatalysts for Li-S batteries is presented, including but not limited to vacancy engineering, heteroatom doping, single atom doping, band regulation, alloying, and heterostructure engineering. The future perspectives and challenges are also proposed for designing high-efficient electrocatalysts to construct high-energy-density and long-lifetime Li-S batteries. Graphical Abstract We have summarized the fascinating strategies for regulating the electronic structure of electrocatalysts to accelerate sulfur redox conversion, which could significantly improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Catalytic effect Electronic modification Shuttle effect Redox kinetics 1 Introduction With the increasing demand for portable electronics and electric vehicles, the energy densities powered by conventional lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are approaching their theoretical limits [1–4]. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, among the state-of-the-art next-generation energy storage systems, has been regarded as one of the most promising successors to LIBs [5–10]. The theoretical gravimetric energy density of Li-S batteries is 2600 Wh kg−1, which is three to five times higher than that of LIBs [11–14]. Besides, elemental sulfur as the active material possesses the fascinating advantages of low cost, environmentally friendliness, and nature abundance [15–20]. Although Li-S batteries are promising, the practical application is severely hampered by multiple challenges coming from the sulfur cathode, lithium anode [21–24], and electrolyte [25–29]. Here, we mainly focus on the critical concerns regarding the sulfur cathode. The first one is the insulation characteristic of elemental sulfur (5 × 10−30 S cm−1, room temperature) and discharge product lithium sulfide (Li2S, 3.6 × 10−7 S cm1, room temperature) [30–32], which inhibits the active materials from being used directly as cathode. The second one is the large volumetric changes up to 80% between S and Li2S during cycling [33–40]. The third one is the notorious shuttle effect of polysulfides. During the charge/discharge process, the generated long-chain polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 < x ≤8) will dissolve into the electrolyte and diffuse between the cathode and the anode, leading to the participation in the reduction reactions with Li anode and oxidation reactions at the cathode side [41–45]. This inevitable shuttle effect causes low utilization of active materials and rapid capacity fading [46–50]. On the other hand, to meet the demand for high energy density of practical applications for Li-S batteries, high sulfur loading of more than 5 mg cm−2, high sulfur content of more than 70%, and low electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio of less than 6 µL mg−1 are indispensable [16–19]. However, with increasing the sulfur loading and reducing the E/S ratio, more polysulfides will accumulate on the substrate surface during the cycling process, also resulting in sluggish polysulfide redox conversion and rapid inactivation of the substrate surface by forming Li2S2/Li2S passivation layer. The typical strategies to address the first two challenges mentioned above include constructing high electronic conductive networks [51–56], reducing the size of sulfur particles [57–61], rationally designing flexible electrode structures [62–67], or reserving extra space for the active materials [68,69], and great progress has been achieved. However, it is still a formidable challenge to inhibit the shuttle effect because polysulfides are inevitably formed during cycling. In fact, all-solid-state Li-S batteries can avoid the generation of polysulfides and completely eradicate the shuttle effect by replacing traditional organic liquid electrolytes with solid electrolytes [70–74]. However, all-solid-state Li-S batteries have shortcomings of inferior reaction kinetics, electrolyte sensitivity to moisture, and severely low sulfur content in the cathode, which are challenging for commercialization [37,75–79]. Therefore, strenuous efforts have been exerted over the past few decades to suppress the polysulfide shuttle of Li-S batteries with organic electrolytes by utilizing reasonable host materials. So far, various conductive carbon materials, such as micro/mesoporous carbon [80–84], hollow carbon spheres [85–90], carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [91–93], and graphene [94–98], have been widely used as sulfur hosts to confine polysulfides through physical adsorption. However, the weak binding energy between nonpolar carbon substrates and polar polysulfides is inadequate to efficiently suppress the polysulfide shuttle. Therefore, polar functionalized carbons with heteroatom doping (N, S, O, P) and defect engineering [99–102] have been developed as sulfur hosts, which are able to capture the polysulfides via chemical adsorption through the formation of chemical bonds between polysulfides and polar hosts. These strategies are based on the perspective of inhibiting the diffusion of polysulfides by using physical confinement or chemical adsorption to passively restrict polysulfide diffusion. However, the shuttle effect is not only derived from the diffusion of dissolved polysulfides but also caused by the slow conversion kinetics between polysulfides and Li2S2/Li2S [103–106]. In light of this, the introduction of electrocatalysts that can accelerate the redox kinetics of polysulfides is considered to be a more effective strategy to suppress shuttle effect, particularly under practical applications [103,106]. This is because for the substrates with only adsorption function, the sluggish redox kinetics of adsorbed polysulfides results in a saturation of polysulfides on substrate surfaces. Therefore, further polysulfide adsorption is restricted and inactive sulfur species accumulate in each cycle, thereby leading to the structure degradation and capacity fading [63–67]. In contrast, the catalytic materials can not only entrap polysulfides but also accelerate the redox conversions of polysulfides by facile electrons/ions transfer, resulting in an unsaturated state of polysulfides. Therefore, further entrapment of polysulfides is feasible and smooth adsorption-conversion of polysulfides is realized [107–110]. Up to now, various catalytic substrates, such as metal oxides [111–115], metal sulfides [116–120], metal nitrides [121–123], metal phosphides [124–126], and metal carbides [127–129], have been developed and utilized as sulfur host materials. The classification of these catalytic materials has been comprehensively reviewed in term of their intrinsically physical and chemical properties in previous reports [5–7]. In fact, the catalytic activity of electrocatalysts is essentially determined by their electronic structure. Therefore, rational regulation of the electronic structure plays a pivotal role in realizing high-efficient electrocatalysts. The spin ordering, density of state (DOS) and energy band structure intrinsically characterize the electronic behaviors. In this review, we mainly summarize the strategies for optimizing the electronic structure (e.g., spin state, DOS, and band structure) of electrocatalysts for Li-S batteries and establish the relationship between electronic structure and catalytic activity. The employed strategies are classified as follows: (1) vacancy engineering; (2) heteroatom doping; (3) single atom doping; (4) band regulation; (5) alloying; and (6) heterostructure engineering. The remaining challenges and prospects are also proposed for further rational guidelines of designing electrocatalysts to regulate Li-S chemistry. 2 Principles of sulfur redox reactions and roles of catalytic materials Since the accumulation of polysulfides on the surface of electrocatalysts is the key reason for the sluggish transformation and shuttle of polysulfides, rational design of electrocatalysts for accelerating polysulfide reaction kinetics is considered as an effective strategy to suppress shuttle effect [6–8]. During the discharge process, S8 is gradually reduced to soluble polysulfides and finally to insoluble Li2S through the following steps (Figs. 2(a) and 2(b) ) [15,130,131]. The first step of solid-liquid reaction process corresponds to the solid sulfur ring-opening reduction to the long-chain Li2S8 at the potential of ~2.4 V (vs. Li/Li+). The second step of liquid-liquid reaction process is the further reduction of the long-chain Li2S8 to short chains Li2S x (4 ≤ x ≤ 8) at ~2.3 V, while the third step of liquid-solid reaction process corresponds to the two-phase reaction from short-chain Li2S x (4 ≤ x ≤ 8) to solid Li2S2 at ~2.1 V. The last step is the reduction from solid Li2S2 to solid Li2S. Notably, steps 1 and 2 are relatively easy due to the low reaction energy barrier. However, steps 3 and 4 are tough because of high energy barrier and thus sluggish reaction kinetics, which are considered as the rate-determining steps of sulfur redox kinetics [132,133]. Moreover, the discharge product Li2S is preferred to be deposited on the surface of active sites, leading to the gradual deactivation of their catalytic activity. Since 75% of sulfur discharge capacity derives from steps 3 and 4 (1254 mAh g−1), enhancing the reaction kinetics of Li2S precipitation is extremely important for suppressing shuttle effect. During the subsequent charge process, due to the insulating properties of Li2S2/Li2S, an additional driving force is required to facilitate their decomposition [134–136]. Therefore, appropriate electrocatalysts are high required to facilitate the redox kinetics of Li2S2/Li2S precipitation and decomposition to improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. 3 Electronic structure engineering of electrocatalysts Since the conductivity and adsorption strength of the electrocatalysts as the intuitive behavior of the electronic structure directly determine the reaction kinetics, the electronic structure has been identified as an important descriptor to explain the corresponding catalytic behavior [137,138]. The spin ordering, energy band structure, and DOS intrinsically characterize the electronic behaviors. Combining the advanced operando characterizations and powerful simulation methods, the clear images of electronic structure are available via detecting and simulating these characteristics [137,139–142]. Herein, we mainly summarize the modulation of electronic structure of electrocatalyst materials used for Li-S batteries via different strategies, such as vacancy engineering, heteroatom doping, single atom doping, band engineering, alloying, and heterostructure engineering, which are reviewed in details in this section with some representative examples. 3.1 Vacancy engineering Vacancy engineering is considered as one of the most effective strategies for surface modification of electrocatalysts, which aims at creating more active sites and tuning the surface charge-transfer property. Meanwhile, vacancies can significantly promote the electrocatalytic activity by optimizing the surface-adsorption ability for reaction intermediates, which derives from the abundance of localized electrons around vacancies. Additionally, the vacancies can simultaneously tailor the surface hydrophilic property for a better electrolyte contact. Therefore, vacancies can function as adsorption and conversion sites for the polysulfide intermediates, leading to the improved electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries [139]. 3.1.1 Anion vacancies Oxygen vacancies are the most widely used anion vacancies in Li-S batteries due to the following reasons. Firstly, oxygen vacancies with abundant localized electrons can act as active sites for the adsorption and activation of adsorbed products [139]. Secondly, the surface oxygen vacancies possess strong hole and/or electron trapping ability, which effectively suppress the recombination of charge carriers and dramatically reduce the energy barrier for interfacial charge transfer [140]. Therefore, oxygen vacancies can significantly promote the electrochemical properties of Li-S batteries by improving charge transfer capability and enhancing polysulfide affinity. For example, Zhang et al. explored amorphous tantalum oxide with oxygen vacancies (a-Ta2O5–x ) embedded into the microporous carbon (MCN) as a new electrocatalyst toward polysulfide entrapment and conversion [141]. The Ta L3 -edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra reveals that the oxygen vacancies in the Ta2O5–x increase the density of Ta 5d unoccupied states near the Fermi level (Fig. 3(a) )). Meanwhile, oxygen vacancies reduce conduction band minimum (CBM), which can be observed from the Ta L 3 absorption edge energy (E 0) of a-Ta2O5–x . The increased density of Ta 5d unoccupied states near the Fermi level and the reduced CBM significantly reduce the band gap of a-Ta2O5–x /MCN (Fig. 3(b))). Thus, the electrons become more easily striding over the gap and can significantly ameliorate the intrinsic conductivity, and the oxygen-deficient Ta2O5–x catalyst presents higher activity than that of Ta2O5. On the other hand, the Fourier-transformed extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectra (FT-EXAFS, Figs. 3(c) and 3(d)) reveal the stability of oxygen-deficient structure. Therefore, the as-fabricated a-Ta2O5–x @MCN/S cathode presents excellent rate capacity up to 5 C, long-term cyclability over 1000 cycles with an ultralow capacity fading rate of 0.029% per cycle, and high areal capacity of 5 mAh cm−2 under high sulfur loading and low electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) conditions. Oxygen vacancies in other metal oxides, such as Nb2O5–x @MCN [142], TiO2 [143,144], Mn/Ni co-doped CoO/C [145], Fe2O3@Mn3O4 nanosheet [146] and HNb3O8 [147], WO3– x[148], can also generate rich electrons, leading to the enhanced conductivity and fast polysulfide conversion. In addition to oxygen vacancies, sulfur, selenium, and nitrogen vacancies have also been introduced into metal compounds to tailor their electronic structure. For example, Zhang et al. [149] fabricated MXene/1T-2H MoS2-C nanomaterials with sulfur vacancies for boosting the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Large numbers of positively S-vacancy defects generated in MXene/1T-2H MoS2-C surface serve as strong adsorption and activation sites of polysulfides, which accelerate their redox reactions, thereby suppressing polysulfide shuttle. Thus, the MXene/1T-2H MoS2-C-S electrode exhibits an excellent cycle stability, which preserves a high capacity of 799.3 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C after 300 cycles. In addition, Shen et al. [150] developed a Ni3N0.85 electrocatalyst by engineering nitrogen vacancies in a hexagonal Ni3N (Fig. 3(e))), which could enhance the catalytic activity of inert Ni3N and expedite the sulfur redox conversion. To further explore the underlying reason for the accelerated sulfur redox conversion, the relationship between the activation energy barrier of polysulfide conversion and the 3d orbital interactions of the defected Ni3N0.85 is investigated (Fig. 3(f))). Combining with density functional theory (DFT) calculations, it can be seen from the center of the 3d-bands of Ni3N0.85 shifts to the Fermi level (Fig. 3(g))) due to the presence of nitrogen vacancies. Meanwhile, the crystal orbital overlap population (COOP, Fig. 3(h))) analysis shows that Ni3N0.85 has more antibonding states of S–S bonding below the Fermi level than that of Ni3N, indicating that vacancy-rich Ni3N0.85 weakens the S–S bonding and thereby expediting polysulfide conversion. Thus, the vacancy-rich Ni3N0.85@S cathode delivers a high initial capacity of 1200 mAh g−1 for up to 100 cycles at a high loading of 5.2 mg cm−2. Apart from the successful introduction of sulfur and nitrogen vacancies, Tian and co-workers [151] developed catalytically active Sb2Se3–x with rich selenium vacancies for boosting the performance of Li-S system. The defects in the as-fabricated Sb2Se3–x induce a redistribution of the excess electrons among the nearest neighboring atoms to form shallow donor states. In this case, electrons below the Fermi level can leap into the defect level, which creates a hole carrier and lowers the barrier of electron transition to the conduction bands, thus contributing to the enhanced conductivity. Meanwhile, the introduced selenium defects strengthen the chemical affinity to polysulfides. Therefore, rapid sulfur electrochemical conversion is realized. It can be concluded from above studies that the anion vacancies within the electrocatalysts are typically beneficial to accelerating the redox kinetics of polysulfides in Li-S batteries. 3.1.2 Cation vacancies Apart from anion vacancies, cation vacancies also have important prospects in promoting catalytic activity because of their unique active sites and electronic properties [152–154]. For instance, Zhang et al. [154] developed the Fe3–x C@hollow microspheres with enriched Fe-vacancies as advanced sulfur host materials. DOS results shown in Fig. 3(i)) reveal that the Fe defects in the Fe3–x C increase Fe d-band center (–1.3573 eV) compared to the pure Fe3C (–2.0939 eV), thereby enhancing the polysulfide affinity. Meanwhile, the energy barrier of Li2S decomposition on the Fe-defect rich Fe3–x C (0.51 eV) is lower than that on the pure Fe3C (1.72 eV), demonstrating the accelerated Li2S conversion kinetics by the introduction of Fe defects. Correspondingly, the Fe3–x C/S electrode exhibits a high rate capacity up to 5 C and stable cycling over 1000 cycles with a low capacity fading rate of 0.04% per cycle at 1 C. To further clarify the influence of cation vacancies on sulfur redox chemistry, Zhao et al. [152] adopted an in situ extrinsic-metal etching strategy to create the cation vacancies. During the charge/discharge process, the Fe atoms at the angular position of the cubic structure of Ni3FeN could be leached out by polysulfide etching, leading to the formation of a metastable Ni3Fe1–δ N (Fig. 3(j))). The authors infer that the creation of Fe vacancies activates the electrochemically inert Ni3N, exposing abundant active sites for boosting the redox conversion of polysulfides. This study not only reveals the true active sites under aprotic conditions but also deepens the understanding of the chemical conversion of sulfur caused by vacancies. Despite significant progresses have been achieved, there is still a big room to explore vacancy engineering for harnessing robust catalytic capability to boost sulfur reaction kinetics. For example, traditional exfoliation and pyrolysis strategies are usually unable to accurately control the generation of specific types of defects. In this sense, it is imperative to develop effective strategies to achieve the optimized defective catalysts. It is worth noting that chemical vapor deposition, atomic layer deposition, and plasma assisted technologies are considered as promising solutions for the preparation of defective catalysts, yet still lack in-depth exploration in constructing defect sites with a precise and controllable manner. 3.2 Heteroatom doping Similar to the strategy of introducing cation/anion vacancies, heteroatom doping is another encouraging method for enhancing catalytic activity [155]. The employment of heteroatoms or free radicals can disrupt the periodicity of the crystal lattice, resulting in a locally changed electronic structure [156,157]. This change can effectively modify the electric conductivity and surface property of substrate materials and thus enhance their electrocatalytic activity. Therefore, heteroatom doping shows a broad prospect for the rational design of polysulfide conversion mediators for Li-S batteries [158–161]. Herein, typical types of heteroatom doping used for electrocatalyst design, i.e., anion-doped carbon, anion-doped compounds, and cation-doped compounds, are summarized, with particular attention to the sulfur redox conversion regulated by heteroatom doped mediators. 3.2.1 Anion-doped carbon In the field of Li-S batteries, heteroatom-doped carbon materials can not only regulate the uniform distribution of electron of nonpolar carbon surface to localize electron accumulation in heteroatom but also generate special surface functional groups, which afford more active sites for polysulfide adsorption [162–164]. By combining with density functional theory calculations, Hou et al. [165] systematically investigated the interactions between various heteroatoms (B, N, O, F, P, S, and Cl) doped carbon and polysulfides. It is demonstrated that the chemical modification of carbon using N or O heteroatom remarkably enhances the interactions between polysulfides and the carbon substrates through dipole-dipole electrostatic interactions and thus significantly suppress the shuttle effect, allowing high capacity and Coulombic efficiency. In contrast, the interactions between polysulfides and B, S, P, F, and Cl doped carbon substrates are unsatisfactory [165]. Compared with mono-atomic doping, dual-atomic doping can further improve the adsorption capability of polysulfides by synergistic effect [102,166]. For instance, Zhou et al. [167] prepared N, S co-doped graphene sponge and applied it as sulfur host. Based on first-principles calculations, it is revealed that the N, S co-doped graphene sponge shows stronger binding energy towards polysulfides compared to single N or S doped graphene sponge. In addition, N and P co-doped Gr/CNTs@porous carbon hybrid substrate was successfully fabricated by Wu et al. [168], which could generate more defects and active sites in the carbon substrate, thereby improving the polysulfide adsorption and electrochemical performance. The heteroatom doping mentioned above mainly focuses on the inhibition of polysulfide shuttle by enhancing the polysulfide adsorption capability of carbon substrate. To further explore the sulfur redox reactions enabled by the heteroatom doping carbon from a viewpoint of catalytic conversion, Xu et al. [169] calculated the reaction energy barrier of polysulfide conversion during electrochemical reaction process with the assistance of DFT calculations. The calculated adsorption energy between different types of N-doped graphene (graphitic N, pyrrolic N, and pyridinic N) and polysulfides indicates that pyridinic N possesses the highest adsorption energy for polysulfides. This means that pyridinic N atoms are preferential adsorption sites for polysulfide intermediates during the redox reaction process. More importantly, the graphene-four pyridinic N (Gr-4N) shows different reaction rate determining step (Fig. 4(a) )) and smallest limiting energy barrier of 0.12 eV compared to the pure graphene, graphene-two pyridinic N (Gr-2N), and graphene-three pyridinic N (G-3N). Thus, the activity trend in these four cases is Gr-4N > Gr-3N > Gr-2N > Gr, demonstrating that catalytic activity and reaction pathways are strongly dependent on the concentration of N-dopants in graphene. Based on these analysis, the following three criteria are required to obtain a catalyst with high catalytic activity: (1) High conductivity for fast charge transfer; (2) strong binding capability to enhance the adsorption and immobilization for polysulfides; and (3) strong electrocatalytic activity to promote redox kinetics of polysulfide conversion (Figs. 4(b)–(d)). To better understand the fundamental origins of the improved catalytic activity for the co-doped carbon materials, Peng and co-workers [170] developed N,S co-doped holey graphene framework (N,S-HGF) and investigated sulfur reduction reaction process. The activation energy (E a) for each reduction step of polysulfide conversion was investigated by probing the charge transfer resistance at the corresponding voltages under various temperatures. The obtained E a presents the highest value of 0.33 eV for the N, S-HGF at 1.8 V than that at 2.7 V (0.12 eV) and 2.1 V (0.24 eV). This result clearly demonstrates that the conversion of S8 ring molecules to soluble polysulfides is relatively easy, whereas the conversion of polysulfides into insoluble Li2S2/Li2S is difficult. Meanwhile, compared to mono-atomic N-HGF or S-HGF doping, the N,S-HGF substrate delivers the smallest E a, indicating the facile reaction kinetics with the introduction of N and S dual-atoms. Meanwhile, the N, S co-doped HGF substrate presents a good compromise of LiS binding (–2.14 eV) and consequently a low overpotential. The DOS pattern result further reveals an intermediate p-band center energy caused by the dual-doping, thus leading to a moderate bonding energy with the LiS radical and eventually resulting in an enhanced electrocatalytic activity for sulfur reduction reaction process. 3.2.2 Anion-doped metal compounds Metal compounds generally have high polysulfide adsorption capacity compared to carbon substrates, therefore doping non-metal atoms (N,P) into metal compounds (e.g., transition metal oxides and sulfides) can further improve their catalytic activity [163,171,172]. For example, Liu et al. [163] fabricated a novel N-doped Co9S8 as an advanced sulfur host. Interestingly, the adsorption structures obtained from the first-principles calculations clearly indicate that the Li atoms tend to bond with the N atoms after the surface doping with N atoms (Figs. 5(a) and 5(b) ). In contrast, the Li and S atoms of polysulfides chemically bond with the S and Co atoms of pristine Co9S8. Meanwhile, the N-doped Co9S8 exhibits higher adsorption capability toward polysulfides. This study reveals that the doped N can simultaneously improve the immobilization capability and catalytic activity of Co9S8, and thereby accelerate polysulfide conversion. In addition, the P-doped CoS2 as a sulfur host was also reported by Liu et al. [172], which can not only significantly improve the polysulfide adsorption but also enhance the catalytic effects. To truly improve the sulfur redox conversion for realizing high-performance Li-S batteries, it is essential to develop a bidirectional electrocatalyst that can simultaneously accelerate both the reduction of polysulfides and the oxidation of Li2S. Wang et al. [171] constructed a new type of bi-functional catalyst by anion N doping in CoSe2 (N-CoSe2). The DOS patterns of N-CoSe2 and CoSe2 (Fig. 5(c))) indicate that new defect levels could be produced by the introduction of N heteroatoms, thus increasing the conductivity of CoSe2. Meanwhile, the d-band center of Co 3d in N-CoSe2 apparently shifts closer to the Fermi level compared to CoSe2, indicating the higher charge carrier density and favorable charge transfer during sulfur redox conversion [173]. The projected density of states (PDOS) of Co 3d further demonstrates that the Co atoms in N-CoSe2 affords more empty orbitals to adsorb polysulfide intermediates (Figs. 5(d) and 5(e)), which is conducive to the polysulfide adsorption. Atomic level analysis shown in Figs. 5(f)–5(i) discloses that N-CoSe2 can form shorter Co–S bonds with sulfur species and simultaneously weaken the S–S bridged bond of Li2S4 and Li–S bond of Li2S, which expedite the polysulfide reduction and Li2S oxidation. Because of these advantages, the fabricated N-CoSe2 bifunctional catalyst delivers a high areal capacity of 9.26 mAh g−1 under a low E/S ratio of 4.4 μL mg−1. Besides, a bidirectional electrocatalyst of porous N-doped Ti3C2 MXene (P-NTC) has also recently been reported by Song et al. [174]. Benefiting from the ample N doping, P-NTC can not only serve as an effective immobilizer for polysulfides but also act as a bifunctional electrocatalyst to promote both the precipitation and decomposition of Li2S. 3.2.3 Cation (metal ion) doped compounds Except anion-doped metal compounds, the doped cation ions (metal atoms) in the metal compounds can also induce lattice deformation and redistribution of internal electrons. These changes can activate the doping atoms and surrounding atoms as active sites to participate in the redox conversion of polysulfides [161,175]. Meanwhile, the charge transfer from the catalytic interface to the adsorbed reactants is facilitated by the electron redistribution [176,177]. The single metal atoms doped in the carbon matrix are widely defined as single-atom materials, which will be discussed separately in this review. In this section, we mainly focus on the metal atoms doped in non-carbon matrices. Metal sulfides, such as MoS2, are widely used in Li-S batteries to restrain the shuttle of polysulfides due to their decent chemical adsorption capacity and catalytic activity [109,178]. Nonetheless, their relatively low conductivity and activity limit the polysulfide conversion kinetics. Liu et al. [179] proposed the use of Co-doped MoS2 to expedite the redox conversion of polysulfides. The calculated formation energies (Figs. 6(a) and 6(b) ) show that Mo atoms (–1.45 eV) are easily replaced by Co atoms. The formation of 1T MoS2 is preferred compared to 2H MoS2 when the Co doping content in MoS2 is higher than 0.2, owing to the low formation energy of 1T phase MoS2 (Fig. 6(a)) and 6(b)). Besides, the formation energy of sulfur vacancies in MoS2 also decreases from 3.38 eV (2H MoS2) to 1.92 eV (1T Co-doped MoS2) with Co doping. Clearly, the doped Co atoms promote the transition from semiconducting 2H phase to metallic 1T phase accompanied with the introduction of sulfur vacancies, which thereby enhances the electron transfer and catalytic activity (Fig. 6(c))). In addition, Co-doped SnS2 [180], Co-doped TiO2–x [181], and Ni-doped zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 [182] have also been reported to accelerate the polysulfide conversion in Li-S batteries. Catalysts with bidirectional catalytic function can also be generated by the cationic doping. For example, Wang et al. [183] designed a bifunctional electrocatalyst by doping Co cations into MoSe2 (Co-MoSe2) that was in situ hybridized with MXene nanosheets. Mo K-edge EXAFS spectra shown in Fig. 6(d)) implies the decrease of Mo-Mo coordination, which derives from the substitution of Mo atoms by Co atoms in MoSe2. The partial substitution of Mo atoms by Co atoms also leads to coordination unsaturation of Se atoms near Co atoms, thereby activating the inert two-dimensional basal plane of MoSe2. The total density of states (TDOS) (Fig. 6(e))) shows that both the valence bands and conduction bands shift toward the Fermi level after doping Co cations into MoSe2, thus resulting in a narrower band gap. Meanwhile, the DOS of Co-MoSe2 is also obviously closer to the Fermi level compared to MoSe2, which derives from Mo d, Se p, and Co d orbitals (Fig. 6(f))). The PDOS plots (Fig. 6(g))) further confirm that the conduction and valence bands of Se-p, Co-d and Mo-d shift towards the Fermi level after doping Co atoms into MoSe2 lattice planes. Accordingly, the doping Co atoms into the MoSe2 can significantly enhance the electronic conductivity of MoSe2 and provide strong interactions between polysulfides and Co-MoSe2, leading to the enhanced catalytic activity for fast redox kinetics. In addition to replacing the original atoms in the substrates, heteroatoms can also be embedded into the structural gaps of the substrates. For example, Yang and co-workers [184] fabricated ultrathin-layered cation-doped Sn-MoO3 nanoribbons, in which the Sn atoms intercalated into the MoO3 van der Waals gap (Fig. 6(h))). The DOS patterns of pure and Sn-MoO3 slab show that the valence electrons of Sn have partially transferred to MoO3 slab. Meanwhile, the infused electrons from intercalated Sn atoms have replaced the original bandgap with the spreading states around Fermi level, resulting in the metallic properties of Sn-MoO3 (Figs. 6(i) and 6(j)). Besides, these spreading states around Fermi level are mainly contributed from Mo and O atoms, which are easily to be affected by adsorbates and will further lead to the enhanced binding strength. As expected, the DOS pattern of the adsorbed Li2S4 reveals that electrons were transferred from lower states into upper levels after Sn intercalation (Figs. 6(k) and 6(l)). The increased electrons in the upper states near Fermi level is easier to participate into the sulfur redox reactions, thus leading to better electrochemical performance. Apart from cation/anion doping, heteroatom doping using simultaneous cation (Co) and anion (P) modifications of MoS2 could also improve the sulfur conversion reaction [185]. The doping of Co turns MoS2 from 2H phase to 1T phase, thereby increasing the electrical conductivity of MoS2. Meanwhile, the formation of Co-P coordination sites on the surface of the catalyst are effective for the polysulfide redox reaction. This work provides the first direct evidence that heteroatom co-doping is beneficial to polysulfide conversion. Note that although the doping strategy in the form of either substitution or attachment to conductive hosts is widely used to modulate the chemisorption capability and electrical conductivity, multiple factors, such as doping sites, dopant distribution, and doping content, could greatly influence the catalytic properties of designed materials and their impact on the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries need further investigation. 3.2.4 Single atom doping Single atom catalysts (SACs) are rapidly becoming a fascinating research frontier in the field of catalysis [186,187]. Benefiting from the maximized atom-utilization efficiency and well-defined catalytic active sites, SACs showcase a great potential in promoting various electrochemical reactions with improved selectivity. The uniformity and simplicity of the SACs structure make it possible to accurately characterize and identify the active sites, thereby deepening the understanding the relationship between the structure and the catalytic effect at the atomic level. Recently, SACs with unique atomic structures have been introduced into Li-S batteries, exhibiting excellent catalytic activity in accelerating polysulfide conversion [188,189]. Yang and co-workers [190] first reported the application of Fe single atom loaded on N-doped carbon as a sulfur host for Li-S batteries. However, the lack of sufficient evidences to clearly define the coordination structure of Fe single atom makes its single atom catalyst somewhat controversial. Until 2019, Du et al. [191] prepared SACs of Co-embedded N-doped graphene (Co-N/G) and used it as a sulfur host. They clearly revealed the coordination environment of Co single atom with a Co-N4 square-planar structure (i.e., Co atom coordinates with four N atoms). The Co-N coordination center can serve as a bifunctional electrocatalyst to promote both the formation and decomposition of Li2S. Therefore, the as-fabricated Co-N/G electrode allows a high utilization of sulfur active materials even with a high sulfur mass ratio of 90 wt%. After that, atomically dispersed Fe/C2N [192], single atom Zn-MXene [193], single atom Co-N-doped carbon nanosheet [194], and O, N-coordinated single atom Mn [195] have also been employed into Li-S system. Especially, Zhou et al. fabricated a variety of single atom materials, including single atom Fe, Mn, Ru, Zn, Co, Cu, V, and Ag, on N-doped graphene (NG). Among these single atom materials, V single atom on NG shows the smallest decomposition barrier (1.10 eV), lowest lithium ion diffusion barriers (0.23 eV), and highest polysulfide chemisorption capability (3.38 eV), thereby presenting high catalytic activity to expedite sulfur redox reactions [196]. Precisely regulating the coordination structure of the metal center and further enhancing the catalytic activity of the metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-NC) electrocatalyst is extremely important to realize high-performance Li-S batteries [197,198]. It is well known that the nonpolar M-N4 coordination is unfavorable for the adsorption of intermediate products owing to the high electronegativity of the plane-symmetric N atoms around the metal atom [199]. In contrast, the M-N2 coordination can present excellent electrochemical activity because of their highly unsaturated coordination [200]. Based on the above consideration, uniform and stable Fe-N2 coordination structure was successfully constructed by Qiu et al. [201] and used as a sulfur host. The DOS in Fig. 7(a) ) reveals that Fe-N2/carbon nitride (Fe-N2/CN) possesses more states near the Fermi energy level than that of carbon nitride (CN), indicating that the Fe atom doping can improve the conductivity of CN, which is beneficial for the electron transfer in the sulfur redox conversion. The PDOS of Fe-N2/CN (Fig. 7(b))) shows sharp peaks that are attributed to the Fe 3d electrons, which play a positive role in modulating the polysulfide adsorption and interfacial electron transfer. Meanwhile, the calculated binding energy of Li2S adsorbed on the Fe-N2 (–3.12 eV) is much higher than that on the CN (–1.51 eV). Besides, the Fe-N2 sites also reduce the decomposition energy barrier of Li2S (Fig. 7(c))). Thus, the unsaturated Fe-N2 can serve as a bifunctional site for entrapping and activating polysulfides to accelerate the reversible conversion from S8 to Li2S. Eventually, the as-fabricated Fe-N2/CN@S cathode delivers a high rate capacity and stable cycling performance. To further optimize the polysulfide adsorption and catalytic process in Li-S system, Ma et al. [202] constructed an integrated catalyst containing Fe single atom and Fe2N nanocrystals co-decorated on N-doped graphene (SA-Fe/Fe2N@NG). The symmetrical charge distribution of the planar SA-Fe structure allows only top-site adsorption of polysulfides (Figs. 7(d) and 7(f)). By contrast, an asymmetric electron distribution of Fe2N exhibits tends to combine sulfur atoms through the bridge sites of two adjacent iron sites, which is attributed to the triangular pyramid coordination of Fe-3N (Figs. 7(e) and 7(g)). Besides, the abundant and interconnected Fe-N coordination sites in Fe2N help to alleviate the saturation adsorption effect caused by the limited Fe active sites of single atom Fe. Thus, SA-Fe/Fe2N@NG exhibits a high adsorption capability toward polysulfides (Fig. 7(h))). The low Gibbs free energy (0.556 eV) on SA-Fe (Fig. 7(i))) indicates that the reduction from Li2S2 to Li2S is thermodynamically favorable on SA-Fe sites. Notably, the lower free energy profile of Li2S decomposition on Fe2N (0.138 eV) compared with that on NG (3.117 eV) and SA-Fe (1.395 eV) reveals the facile delithiation kinetics with the introduction of Fe2N (Figs. 7(j)–7(l)). These results reveal that the synergistic Fe2N and SA-Fe composite sites improve the chemisorption and catalytic conversion of polysulfides. Up to now, the preparation of SACs has always confronted issues such as the high surface free energy of isolated metal atoms, thereby resulting in the easy aggregation of metal atoms and subsequent sacrifice the catalytic activity. To this end, most available SACs tend to reduce the metal loading (usually below 1.0 wt%) to maintain the isolated state of metal atoms without aggregation, which severely limits the practical application of SACs [191,203]. To realize high performance Li-S batteries, host materials containing a high content of single metal atoms is required to provide abundant active sites to achieve enhanced polysulfide immobilization and their fast transformation. Co single-atom catalyst embedded in N-doped carbon with a high Co content of 15.3 wt% (CoSA-N-C) was fabricated by Li et al. [194]. The high-content Co-N species in CoSA-N-C not only chemically entrap the dissolved polysulfides but also significantly promote the transformation from polysulfides to Li2S. In addition, the CoSA-N-C also efficiently catalyzes the oxidation of Li2S into polysulfides. Therefore, CoSA-N-C@S electrode with high Co content delivers an outstanding electrochemical performance with high sulfur utilization (1574 mAh g−1 at 0.05 C), superior rate capability (624 mAh g−1 at 5 C), and excellent cycle stability (capacity fade rate of 0.035% per cycle for 1000 cycles at 1 C). To realize the high energy density of Li-S batteries, it is necessary to further increase the loading of SACs. Moreover, selecting a suitable support material for the single atom metals not only helps the uniform distribution of single atoms without agglomeration but also facilitates the charge transfer kinetics of the electrochemical reaction. Currently, the existing carrier materials are mainly nano-carbon materials. Researchers should pay more attention to other two-dimensional nanomaterials with novel structures. On the other hand, different single atom metals with distinctive structures and properties may display different catalytic effects for polysulfide conversion, and therefore, designing multiple single atom metals for specific catalytic conversion effects of Li-S batteries is also of great significance. 3.3 Band engineering Generally, interfacial interactions involving surface adsorption and interfacial charge transfer play a crucial role in the electrochemical performance of sulfur cathodes [204,205]. According to the Sabatier principle, too weak adsorption between host materials and polysulfides cannot be beneficial to the interfacial electron/ion transfer and will result in severe shuttle effect, while too strong chemisorption with stable configuration may also impede the ion diffusion and subsequent redox conversion [206]. Therefore, modifying the interfacial interactions by regulating the electronic states of sulfur hosts is important for polysulfide redox reaction. For transition metal-based compounds composed of metallic cations and nonmetallic anions, the partially filled d orbitals of the metallic cations are generally considered as the active sites for the charge transfer and polysulfide redox reactions [150,207]. Therefore, adjusting the adsorption energy can be achieved by regulating the position of the d bands. For instance, Shen et al. [150] proposed a strategy of tuning the d bands of electrocatalysts to enhance polysulfide redox kinetics. After engineering N vacancies in the Ni3N, the Ni–Ni bond length of Ni3N0.85 increases and the position of d bands is elevated, thereby enhancing adsorption capability of polysulfides and expediting their conversion. The d band modulation strategy is also reported by alloying Co to the metal sites of Ni2P (Ni2Co4P3) to accelerate the reaction kinetics of polysulfides. DOS analysis (Figs. 8(a) and 8(b) ) reveals that the Co 3d bands in Ni2Co4P3 is higher than the Ni 3d bands in Ni2P and Ni2Co4P3. Since the Co 3d bands have a lower filling fraction and higher center than Ni 3d bands, stronger adsorption capability toward polysulfide molecules is achieved [207]. Meanwhile, Ni2Co4P3 weakens the S–S bonds and reduces the activation energy of polysulfide conversion (Fig. 8(c))). As a consequence, the polysulfide shuttle is effectively reduced, leading to the excellent cycling stability. In addition to adopting d band modulation of metal elements to expedite polysulfide conversion, p band regulation of nonmetallic elements has also attracted much attention. For example, Zhou et al. [208] disclosed the adjustment mechanism of Li-S chemistry by the p band engineering of nonmetallic anions at the atomic level. They fabricated a variety of Co-based compounds (CoS2, Co4N, Co3O4 and CoP) with fixed metal cation and varied non-metal anions, and systematically studied the kinetic behaviors of Li-S chemistry. The DOS shown in Fig. 8(d)) reveals that the p band center of CoP possesses a remarkable upshift with respect to Fermi level, thereby enabling a reduced energy gap between the anion 2p and cobalt 3d band centers (Fig. 8(e))). Especially, the P anion atoms are softer with less electron pulling force than the O and S atoms in various Co-based compounds, which leads to an increase in the energy of the bonding state and a decrease in the energy gap between the antibonding and bonding orbitals. This further leads to higher electronic energy because the anion has more hybridization and contribution to the valence band electrons, thereby promoting electron transfer and interfacial redox kinetics. Importantly, the CoP exhibits low d-p band centers, small redox potential of S6 2– and S4 2– (Fig. 8(f))), low Li2S diffusion energy (Fig. 8(f))) as well as mild adsorption capability for Li2S6 (Fig. 8(g)), 4.13 eV) compared to other Co-based compounds. As a consequence, the CoP presents higher catalytic activity than t other Co-based compounds. This work reveals that the position of the p bands from the non-metallic anions of electrocatalysts plays an important role in Li-S chemistry by adjusting the interface electron transfer kinetics. It is known from the quantum chemistry that the valence electrons play a crucial role in the formation and breaking of bonds among various elements [209]. For metal-based compounds containing metal cations and non-metal anions, the energy level of the electrons in the p orbitals and d orbitals will directly affect the formation/breaking of the bonds. Based on above theory, the d-p band model was successfully applied into the Fe-based materials (Fe3O4@C, FeS@C, Fe3N@C) in Li-S system [210]. The p-band centers of non-metal anions (O, C, S, and N elements) and d-band centers of metal cation (Fe) based on the DOS is shown in Fig. 8(h)). Among these Fe-based compounds, Fe3C shows the smallest average difference between the center of the d-bands and the p-bands (∆p-d), following the order of ∆p-d (Fe3C) < ∆p-d (Fe3O4) < ∆p-d (FeS) < ∆p-d (Fe3N). Meanwhile, the relationship between ∆p-d center and the reaction voltage of Li2S4 (Fig. 8(i))) clearly reveals that a smaller energy band difference (∆p-d) corresponds to a smaller reaction voltage. More importantly, the reduction of the ∆p-d center reduces the energy barrier of S-S bond breaking, thus enhancing the reaction kinetics of polysulfide conversion. The radial distribution function of g(r)s–s in Fig. 8(j)) further confirms the reduced energy barrier of S–S bond breaking. As shown in Fig. 8(j)), the radius of the first peak, which corresponds to the distance between adjacent S atoms, is 2.05 Å for graphene and Fe3O4, and this value is 2.15 Å for Fe3C. Obviously, the distance between S molecules on Fe3C is more stretched than that on graphene and Fe3O4, which means that Li2S6 molecules on Fe3C have the most significant degree of intermolecular bond breakage. This result demonstrates that the reduction of the ∆p-d center reduces the energy barrier of S–S bond breaking and a better catalyst ability of Fe3C for the polysulfides. 3.4 Alloying engineering Alloy engineering is another commonly adopted method for manufacturing high-performance electrode materials for Li-S batteries [211–215]. By alloying with other metals, the electronic structures of electrocatalysts can be tailored by regulating their compositions, which can boost the electrocatalytic performance [214,215]. For example, Liu et al. [215] designed a Pt-Ni core shell bimetallic catalyst and used it as sulfur host. The Pt 4f X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of Pt-Ni alloy catalyst (Fig. 9(a) )) obviously shifts to low binding energy compared to pure Ni, revealing the electron transfer from Ni to Pt. Therefore, Pt-Ni bimetal shows the highest occupied molecular orbital-lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (HOMO-LUMO) gap, indicating the low energy barrier of polysulfide conversion reaction. Meanwhile, the Pt-Ni bimetal presents high adsorption capacity toward polysulfides (Figs. 9(b) and 9(c)). Therefore, the electrocatalytic activity of bimetal Pt-Ni is remarkably improved. Eventually, the as-fabricated Pt-Ni bimetal demonstrates a decent cycle stability, which preserves high capacity of approximate 600 mAh g−1 at 1 C after 300 cycles. Inspired by this research, other alloy catalysts, such as Co x Sn y [216], Co-Fe [211,217], and Co-Te [218], have also been developed to accelerate the polysulfide conversion. Among these alloy catalyst materials, Song et al. [218] found an interesting phenomenon that the sulfur-poisoned transition metals can be avoided by alloying strategy (Co-Te alloy). Alloying Co with metal Te changes the sulfur adsorption sites and the corresponding binding energies, which enables intact adsorption of S8. The ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations reveal that the structure of S8 remains almost intact when approaching the surface of CoTe2 (Figs. 9(d) and 9(e)) and the adsorption configuration of S8 on CoTe2 remains ring-like S8 molecule by forming two Co–S bonds, indicating that the sulfur poisoning can be inhibited on the surface of CoTe2. In contrast, inevitable disassociation of S8 is observed on the Co surface, and the adsorption geometry of S8 on Co is that eight S atoms bind with the surface. Meanwhile, the Gibbs free energy of polysulfide reduction on the surface of CoTe2 is lower than on the poisoned Co, suggesting that the sulfur reduction process is thermodynamically more favorable on the surface of CoTe2. These merits render Co-Te alloy an excellent catalyst which significantly boosts the sulfur redox reactions and restrains polysulfide shuttle. Thus, sulfur cathode using Co-Te alloy catalyst exhibits a high rate capability of 898 mAh g−1 at 2 C together with a low capacity decay of 0.03% after 1000 cycles. However, the above mentioned Co-based or Pt-based alloy catalysts possess disadvantages of high cost and scarce resources as well as toxic characteristic, which are not suitable for the commercial application of Li-S batteries. Therefore, it is urgent to develop cheap and non-toxic alloy catalytic materials. The low-cost and eco-friendly Ni is known for its high alloying efficiency with many transition metals in different mass ratios [219], which makes it easier to develop a wide range of composition-dependent bimetallic Ni alloys for potentially large-scale application in Li-S batteries. Thus, alloying metal Ni with a low-cost and non-toxic metal is more suitable for improving catalyst activity. For example, nickel-boron (Ni-B) alloy nanoparticles embedded into the carbon nanotube microspheres (CNTMs) have been used as sulfur hosts in Li-S batteries [213]. Ni-B alloy can not only entrap polysulfides through the formation of Ni–S and B–S bonds but also exhibit high catalytic capability toward the conversion of polysulfides. In addition, a cost-effective Ni-Fe alloy is also confirmed to be an efficient catalyst to accelerate the conversion reaction of polysulfide intermediates (Fig. 9(f))) [220]. Note that the alloy catalysts currently employed in Li-S batteries are all dense particles, which not only significantly reduces the active sites but also increases unnecessary mass. Therefore, it is important to rationally design alloy catalysts with three-dimensional porous structure to help further improving the corresponding catalytic activity. 3.5 Heterostructures Design of heterostructures is another promising strategy to construct active interfaces for electrocatalysis, which can create new catalytic sites by modulating the interfacial electronic structure and lattice strain [221–223]. Unlike alloying with one or more other metals, heterostructure engineering generally involves the hybridization of different kinds of compounds with intimate interfaces, such as carbon-metal compound interfaces [224,225], metal compound-metal compound interfaces [222,223], and metal compound-polymer interfaces [226]. To better understand the effect of electronic structure modulation on the catalytic activity of heterostructures, herein we focus on the metal compound-metal compound heterostructures. For the metal-compound based heterostructures, the rapid conversion of polysulfides is achieved by adsorbing-diffusion-transforming mechanism, which can sufficiently exert the advantages of each component [223]. One of the pioneering works is the fabrication of novel MoS2-MoN heterostructure [227]. By combining with the respective advantages of high conductivity of MoN and fast Li ion diffusion accelerated by MoS2, the hetero-interface ensures fast redox conversion from dissolved polysulfides into insoluble Li2S (Fig. 10(a) )). The assembled battery delivers decent capacity and excellent capacity retention at high sulfur loading condition. After that, a variety of heterostructured catalytic materials, such as CoSe2/MoS2 [228], TiO2-TiN [229], MoC-MoO x [230], VO2-VN [231], TiO2-MXene [232], TiN-sulfur-doped oxide layer [233], MO x -MXene (M: Ti, V, and Nb) [234], and V8C7-VO2 [235] and NiO-NiCo2O4 [236], have been designed and reported. Different from above catalytic conversion by heterostructures, Yang et al. [237] found that the deposition morphology of Li2S can also be regulated through a rationally designed MoN@SnO2 nanodot heterostructure. The formed high-accessible interfaces serve as the facile nucleation sites to guide the three-dimensional growth of Li2S, which avoids the surface passivation and facilitates the polysulfide conversion (Figs. 10(b) and 10(c)). Meanwhile, the metallic Mo2N microbelts with high electrical conductivity and good catalytic activity can effectively enhance the reaction kinetics of polysulfides and provide a large surface area for Li2S deposition, while the SnO2 nanodots can effectively entrap polysulfides. Thus, the assembled MoN@SnO2/S cathode delivers a high capacity of 738.3 mAh g−1 after 550 cycles (0.5 C) with a low capacity decay of 0.025% per cycle. Even with under a high sulfur loading of 9.0 mg cm−2 and a low E/S ratio of 5 μL mg−1, excellent cycle stability is also obtained at 0.5 C. Obviously, most of the reported electrocatalysts only work for one direction sulfur reduction reaction, while the oxidation of Li2S by electrocatalysts is largely ignored. If the designed electrocatalyst cannot promote the decomposition of reactive Li2S, it will gradually evolve into a dense passivation layer during repeated cycling owing to the high decomposition barrier of Li2S. Wang et al. [238] proposed a typical bidirectional catalyst of TiO2-Ni3S2 heterostructure to accelerate both the reduction of dissolved polysulfides and the oxidation of Li2S to suppress the catalyst surface passivation. More specifically, during the discharge process, TiO2 presents a strong adsorption capability toward polysulfides and the high catalytic activity of Ni3S2 effectively accelerates the polysulfide reduction. During the subsequent oxidation process, both Ni3S2 and TiO2 exhibit high catalytic oxidation activity toward Li2S, refreshing the catalyst surface. Therefore, the assembled TiO2-Ni3S2@S cathode shows a low capacity decay of 0.038% per cycle for 900 cycles at 0.5 C and excellent cyclic stability with a capacity retention of 65% over 500 cycles at 0.3 C under a sulfur loading of 3.9 mg cm−2. In order to more deeply understand the heterogeneous strategy, Ye et al. [239] developed a two-dimensional MoN-VN heterostructure as a sulfur host (Fig. 10(d))) to gain an atomic-level understanding of polysulfide adsorption. Mo L-edge near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) results (Fig. 10(e))) show that the peak positions of LIII-edge and LII-edge for MoN-VN (2524.0 and 2624.3 eV) shift toward high photon energy compared to that of MoN (2523.7 and 2624.0 eV), indicating a higher oxidation state of Mo in MoN-VN. This probably results from the decreased electron density of Mo in MoN-VN heterostructure owing to the strong coupling between MoN and VN. Meanwhile, a slightly positive shift of Mo XPS spectra (Fig. 10(f))) for the MoN-VN heterostructure further confirms the coupling between MoN and VN. More importantly, MoN-VN heterostructure presents a higher Ep position of the Mo density of state (DOS, Fig. 10(g))) compared with that of MoN. As is known from the orbital hybridization theory, the higher Ep position results in a lower occupancy of anti-bonding states, leading to a stronger adsorption of polysulfides. Based on the tightly coupled interface and enhanced adsorption capability, the MoN-VN@S cathode delivers a high rate capacity of 708 mAh g−1 at 2 C and a low capacity decay of 0.068% per cycle over 500 cycles. Although great progress has been made for the heterostructures used for Li-S batteries, there are still many controversies regarding the special adsorption-diffusion-transfor- mation mechanism. More direct evidences are highly needed to reveal the migration of polysulfides among each component in the heterostructures. Meanwhile, it is also necessary to further explore the origins of the different catalytic activities of heterostructures with different component ratios in combination with theoretical calculations. 4 Conclusions and future outlook Practical application of Li-S batteries is severely impeded by their inferior cycle stability and poor rate performance, which mainly derives from the polysulfide shuttle. Various electrocatalysts have been employed in Li-S batteries, which can expedite the conversion of polysulfides into the insoluble products and are considered as one of the most effective strategies to suppress the shuttle effect. Regulating the electronic structure of electrocatalysts is the key to accurately and controllably regulate the catalytic performance of electrocatalysts in the polysulfide redox process. In this review, we mainly summarize the fascinating strategies to tailor the electronic structures of electrocatalysts, including vacancy engineering, heteroatom doping, single atom doping, band regulation, alloying, and heterostructure engineering. The relationship between the electronic structure of catalytic materials and their catalytic activity is described in details, aiming to provide a rational guidance for the precise design of electrocatalysts with specific activities. Despite significant progress has been made in the past few years, the employment of electrocatalyst materials into Li-S batteries is still in the early stages, with many remaining challenges in developing ideal electrocatalysts for Li-S batteries: (1) Considering that the electronic structure of electrocatalysts greatly affects the physicochemical characteristics and subsequent electrochemical performance of the Li-S batteries, more effective strategies, e.g., precise regulation of doping atom/vacancy concentration, doping/vacancy type, and coordination environment of single atom metals, should be developed to finely modulate the electronic structures (2) The precise identification of structural characteristics (such as the arrangement of atoms in alloys, heterostructure interface and position of the doped atoms or vacancies) is the key to investigate the relationship between the electronic structure and physicochemical properties of electrocatalysts, which is still challenging. Thus, advanced characterization technologies such as XAS, cryo electron microscopy, and Cs-corrected TEM, should be employed to offer in-depth insight into the structure activity relationships. (3) Precise identification of the real catalytic active sites of the electrocatalysts in Li-S batteries is of great significance yet challenging. For example, previous literatures revealed that Fe3O4 [240] and cobalt-containing compounds [241] could react with polysulfides to form sulfides during the electrochemical reaction process, thus the pristine materials cannot be simply defined as the real active sites. Therefore, it is important to track the whole catalytic reaction through in situ characterization techniques (e.g., XAS, Raman, XPS, and XRD) and combine with theoretical models to unambiguously reveal the real active sites. (4) The elaboration of electrocatalysts for Li-S batteries towards practical application should take multiple factors into consideration. The electrocatalysts should possess appropriate chemical adsorption accompanied with high electronic conductivity to ensure the fast electron transfer as required for catalysis. In addition, hierarchical architectures with large numbers of exposed active sites to expedite the redox reaction are also necessary. Moreover, the commonly used electrocatalyst materials are mainly transition metal compounds with high bulk density and a certain degree of toxicity, which can significantly reduce the battery energy density. To improve the overall energy density of Li-S batteries and reduce environmental pollution and battery costs, it is also necessary to develop electrocatalysts derived from light elements rather than heavy or precious metal compounds/metals. (5) To realize high energy density of Li-S batteries, more attention should also be paid to the exploration of high-efficient electrocatalysts under practical applications, such as high-loading cathodes, limited anode excess and lean electrolytes. Notably, when soluble polysulfides are converted into solid Li2S, the active sites will be buried and thus causing loss of activity. The situation gets even worse under practical conditions, such as high sulfur loading, low-temperature, and low E/S ratio. In order to avoid catalyst failure, one of the most promising strategies is to increase the active sites of catalysts through reasonable nanostructure design instead of increasing the catalyst loading. For example, by designing a bidirectional catalyst with a three-dimensional porous structure, more catalytic active sites can be exposed during the discharge process, thereby preventing the catalyst from being completely covered. While for the following oxidation process, bidirectional catalyst also promotes the decomposition of Li2S to refresh electrocatalyst surface. Therefore, the high catalytic activity of electrocatalyst is well retained during the entire electrochemical process. In addition, reducing the size of the catalyst (such as single atom catalyst) can also increase the number of active sites of catalyst, thereby effectively reducing the catalyst loading. In summary, designing sulfur host materials with high catalytic activity has provided a new direction towards high-performance Li-S batteries. We believe that the high-efficiency electrocatalysts with high activity and special functions can be obtained through the coordination of various electronic structure regulation strategies, which can further improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries and also enlighten other energy-related processes based on multi-electron reactions. coredata.dc:description: Abstract With the merits of high energy density, environmental friendliness, and cost effectiveness, lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered as one of the most promising next-generation electrochemical storage systems. However, the notorious polysulfide shuttle effect, which results in low active material utilization and serious capacity fading, severely impedes the practical application of Li-S batteries. Utilizing various electrocatalysts to improve the polysulfide redox kinetics has recently emerged as a promising strategy to address the shuttle effect. Specially, the electronic structure of the electrocatalysts plays a decisive role in determining the catalytic activity to facilitate the polysulfide conversion. Therefore, reasonably modulating the electronic structure of electrocatalysts is of paramount significance for improving the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Herein, a comprehensive overview of the fascinating strategies to tailor the electronic structure of electrocatalysts for Li-S batteries is presented, including but not limited to vacancy engineering, heteroatom doping, single atom doping, band regulation, alloying, and heterostructure engineering. The future perspectives and challenges are also proposed for designing high-efficient electrocatalysts to construct high-energy-density and long-lifetime Li-S batteries.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Recent progress in electronic modulation of electrocatalysts for high-efficient polysulfide conversion of Li-S batteries
